chapter.title: Searching with Beagle
chapter.para: Beagle is a search tool that indexes your personal information space (normally your home directory) in order to carry out search requests. Using Beagle, you can find documents, e-mails and attachments, Web history, IM/IRC conversations, address book contacts, calendar appointments, notes, source code, images, music (and video) files, archives (and their contents) and applications.

sect1.title: Using Beagle
sect1.para: To use Beagle, click Computer , enter your search terms in the Search field, then press Enter. The results are displayed in the Desktop Search dialog box.
You can also access Desktop Search by clicking Computer More Applications System Search or start it from a terminal using the beagle-search.

note.title: Enabling the Search Service
note.para: In order to use Beagle, the search service has to be enabled. In case it is disabled, you will see the Search service is not running page instead of the search results. Enable the service permanently by checking Automatically start service on login and by clicking Start search service.

sect1.para: You can use the results lists to open a file, forward it via e-mail, move it to trash, or display it in the file manager. Simply right-click an item in the results list and select desired option. The options available for an item in the results list are determined by its filetype. Selecting a file in the list displays a preview of the file and information such as the title, path, and date the file was last accessed or modified.

figure.title: Desktop Search Dialog Box With a File Selected

sect1.para: Use the Find In drop-down to limit your search to sources of a specific type (such as applications, documents, pictures, e-mails, Web pages or contacts). The View menu lets you sort the items in your results list according to name, relevance or the date the file was last modified.

listitem.para: You can use both uppercase and lowercase letters in search terms. Searches are not case-sensitive.
To search for optional terms, use OR (for example, apples OR oranges).

important.para: The OR has to be capitalized when used to indicate optional search terms.

listitem.para: To exclude search terms, use a minus sign (-) in front of the term you want to exclude (for example, apples -oranges will find results containing apples but not oranges).
The root form of a search term is used when searching (for example, a search for driving will match drive, drives, and driven).
To search for an exact phrase or word, put quotation marks ("") around the phrase or word.
Common words such as "a”, “the” and “is” are ignored.

sect1.title: Performing a Property Search
sect1.para: By default, the Beagle search tool looks for search terms in the text of documents and in their metadata. To search for a word in a particular property, use property:query. For example, author:john searches for files that have “john” listed in the Author property.

entry.para: Author of the document (same as Creator of the Document)
Creator of the document, mapped to dc:creator (for example, creator of PDF files)
File extension (for example, extension:jpeg or ext:mp3). Use extension: or ext: to search in files with no extension.
Comments and descriptions found in images that have an IPTC caption or Exif comment
F-Spot and DigiKam image tags, and IPTC keywords
Use inarchive:true for files inside an archive
Id of mailing list (for example, dashboard-hackers.gnome.org)
Title of document, mapped to dc:title (for example, title tag of HTML files)

sect1.title: Setting Search Preferences
sect1.para: Use the Search Preferences dialog box to set search preferences for Beagle.

step.para: Click Computer Control Center System Search Settings .
You can also click Search Preferences in the Desktop Search dialog box.
Choose from the following options:

formalpara.title: Start search & indexing services automatically:
formalpara.para: Select this option if you want the search daemon to start automatically when you log in to your session. If you want to use Beagle's Search functionality, the daemon must be running.

formalpara.title: Index data while on battery power:
formalpara.para: Select this option if you want your data to be indexed when your computer is operating on battery power. Disabling this option is particularly useful if you are using &productname; on a laptop and you want to stop indexing when your laptop is running on battery power.

formalpara.title: Index more aggressively while the screen saver is running:
formalpara.para: If the screen saver is running, it is assumed that you are not using computer actively and more resources are dedicated to indexing. This option does not apply if computer is running on battery power.

formalpara.title: Automatically start searching after the user has stopped typing:
formalpara.para: Select this option if you want Beagle to start searching as soon as you stop entering text in the Find field in the Desktop Search window. This option has no effect on the Search field in the main menu.

formalpara.title: Display the search window by pressing:
formalpara.para: Choose the keystrokes that will display the Desktop Search window by specifying any combination of Ctrl, Alt and a function key. F12 is the default keystroke.

step.para: Click OK.

sect1.title: Indexing Other Directories
sect1.para: By default, Beagle indexes your home directory only. If you do not want your home directory to be indexed, uncheck the Index my home directory option on the Indexing tab of the Search Preferences dialog box. If you want to index additional folders, follow these steps:

step.para: Click Computer More Applications System Search Settings .
You can also click Search Preferences in the Desktop Search dialog box.
Click the Indexing tab.
Click Add in the General section of the dialog box.
Select the directory you want to index and click Open.
Make sure you have at least read permissions to the directories you add.
If you want to remove a directory from the list of indexed directories, select it in the list, then click Remove.
Click OK.

sect1.title: Preventing Files and Directories from Being Indexed
sect1.para: Use the Search Preferences dialog box to specify resources that you do not want indexed. These resources can include directories, patterns, mail folders, or types of objects.

step.para: Click Computer More Applications System Search Settings .
Click the Indexing tab.
Click Add in the Privacy section.
Select a resource to exclude from indexing, then specify the path to the resource or filename pattern.
Click OK twice.

sect1.title: Selecting Data Sources to Index
sect1.para: Beagle can index various data sources, data from various applications (for example Evolution mails, memos and tasks, Pidgin conversations, Tomboy notes or Nautilus metadata), files, applications, documentation, man pages and others. To select which data sources Beagle should index, follow these steps:

step.para: Click Computer More Applications System Search Settings .
Click the Data Sources tab.
Check the data sources you want to be indexed.
Click OK.

sect1.title: Disabling Beagle
sect1.para: On low-end computers, Beagle may use too much resources. To disable Beagle, click Computer Control Center System Search Settings Searching and uncheck the Start search & indexing services automatically option.
You can also disable Beagle by editing configuration files in the /etc/beagle/crawl-rules/ directory. To disable Beagle, set option CRAWL_ENABLED to no in all crawl-*files in the directory.
